title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text: This document provides an analysis and simulation of the Cumulative Impact Analysis (CIA) process for clean energy projects as proposed by the Office of Environmental Justice and Equity (OEJE). The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text: This document provides an analysis and simulation of the Cumulative Impact Analysis (CIA) process for clean energy projects as proposed by the Office of Environmental Justice and Equity (OEJE). The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text:
This document provides an analysis and simulation of the Cumulative Impact Analysis (CIA) process for clean energy projects as proposed by the Office of Environmental Justice and Equity (OEJE). The simulation focuses on the Sudbbury-Hudson underground transmission line to illustrate the steps in the CIA process and output generated. The rest of the document proceeds stepwise through the CIA process as described by OEJE.


The first step is to identify the Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of the proposed project. The SGA of a project is defined by the geographic location of the project and its physical footprint, as well as a radius around the project determined by the Energy Facilities Siting Board (EFSB). Table 1 below describes the radii of different energy technologies subject to review for CIA.




Table 1: Specific Geographic Areas for CIA in EFSB Reviews











Energy Technology
Proposed SGA Radius
Rationale




Transmission and Distribution Lines
1/4 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Battery Energy Storage System
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Substation
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Ground-Mounted PV
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Onshore Wind Facility/ Anaerobic Digester > 25MW
1 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


LNG Facility
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Pipeline
1/2 mile
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Fossil Generating Facility
2 miles (non-Major)
5 miles (Major)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations


Compressor Stations
1 mile (no Air permit)
2 miles (non-Major Air)
Construction and visual impacts attenuate beyond this radius; emergency response considerations










The Sudbury-Hudson project was an underground transmission line, which would require a 1/4 mile radius around that project.



To determine if the Sudbury-Hudson project is within or near a BA, we examine whether the SGA (including a buffer of the specified radius) overlaps or intersects with “Burdened Areas” (BAs) as identified by the MassEnviroScreen tool. Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. The block group highlighted in red is a BA.








Figure 1




Figure 1 shows that the SGA of the Sudbury-Hudson transmission line intersects with 14 census block groups, including 1 block group designated as BA. Based on guidance, the project would require a CIA.



Using data from MassEnviroScreen, the project applicant must document the values of all the indicators which inform the cumulative impact score. They must highlight all current indicators which exceed the 50th percentile for the specific indicator. This comprehensive inventory establishes the baseline conditions that will be used to assess the project’s incremental impact.

section: Step 1. Identify Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of Project
text:
Step 1. Identify Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of Project
The first step is to identify the Specific Geographic Area (SGA) of the proposed project. The SGA of a project is defined by the geographic location of the project and its physical footprint, as well as a radius around the project determined by the Energy Facilities Siting Board (EFSB). Table 1 below describes the radii of different energy technologies subject to review for CIA.




Table 1: Specific Geographic Areas for CIA in EFSB Reviews

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
section: Step 2. Determine if SGA Overlaps with BA
text:
Step 2. Determine if SGA Overlaps with BA
To determine if the Sudbury-Hudson project is within or near a BA, we examine whether the SGA (including a buffer of the specified radius) overlaps or intersects with “Burdened Areas” (BAs) as identified by the MassEnviroScreen tool. Figure 1 below is an interactive map showing the transmission line, a 1/4 mile buffer, and the census block groups that intersect with that 1/4 mile buffer. The block group highlighted in red is a BA.








Figure 1




Figure 1 shows that the SGA of the Sudbury-Hudson transmission line intersects with 14 census block groups, including 1 block group designated as BA. Based on guidance, the project would require a CIA.

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
text:
Step 3. Catalog Indicators within SGA
Using data from MassEnviroScreen, the project applicant must document the values of all the indicators which inform the cumulative impact score. They must highlight all current indicators which exceed the 50th percentile for the specific indicator. This comprehensive inventory establishes the baseline conditions that will be used to assess the project’s incremental impact.
Table 2 shows the MassEnviroScreen indicator values for the Burdened Area within the SGA. Items in red exceed the 50th percentile relative to non-Burdened Areas of the state.




Table 2

title: CIA Simulation - SudHud Transmission Line
section: Step 4. Identify Impacts on Key Indicators
text:
Step 4. Identify Impacts on Key Indicators
Using the list of relevant, technology-specific indicators established by the EFSB, the project applicant must assess and document the anticipated impact of the proposed project on each indicator within the SGA. The project applicant must determine whether the project will exacerbate any indicator that already exceeds the 50th percentile threshold or cause any additional indicator to exceed the 50th percentile threshold. If either condition is met, the impact is considered a disproportionate adverse effect for that indicator.
Table 3 below lists the key indicators by technology type as identified by the EFSB.




Table 3











4a. Determine Project Impact Level
The impact on each key indicator is assessed using a qualitative ranking of project impact, which is based on guidelines provided by OEJE and EFSB. Project impact ranks can be one of the following:

No Discernible Impact
Negligible Burdens
Minor Burdens
Moderate Burdens
Major Burdens

The project proponent will be provided with clear and concise guidance on assigning a project impact rank. Guidance should be provided for evaluating impacts on each unique indicator.


4b. Apply Decision Rules to Determine if Disproportionate Adverse Effect
Whether a project’s impact on a key indicator rises to the level of a disproportionate adverse effect is determined based on decision rule matrix as exemplified below in Table 4.




Table 4: Decision Matrix for Project Impacts






Indicator Percentile
Project Impact Rank
Disproportionate Adverse Effect?

No

No

No

No

No

Yes


<30

No


Minor
No


Moderate
No


Major
No
